We begin with Linda Gibbs, New York City's deputy mayor for Health and Human Services.

Nice to have you on TALK OF THE NATION today.
It's nice to be here.
Thank you for inviting me.
And before we get into the why, would you just explain for us a little bit about how this program called Opportunity New York - how it actually works?
The program is a pilot that will involve fifty-one hundred families from six of our highest poverty communities in New York City.

The question that we want to ask is whether or not an incentive-based structure, by providing cash rewards to individuals for accomplishing a set of tasks, can change their trajectory of poverty in a way that existing programs just aren't having an impact.
Mm-hmm.
And who's paying for this?
The program has been funded by a collaboration of philanthropic entities.
And the mayor's thought in starting this is it - it's very new, it's very different from more traditional approach to social services.
And to give it a better chance, we really ought to fund it privately.
Test it with those philanthropic dollars.
It's a perfect role for foundations to have, to try new innovations that aren't necessarily proven.
And then once it establishes whether or not it works, you have the basis of research and knowledge in order to demonstrate whether a taxpayer dollar should be invested to continue it.
And how are you going to be able to tell if it works or not?
Well, we have invested in the most rigorous evaluation that we could.

We've engaged the MDRC, which is a national workforce demonstration provider, who is really well respected across the country, on Capitol Hill, and, in fact, around the world, in doing evaluations, design and evaluation of innovations like this.
And so we've engaged them to help us to design the program and to put together the evaluation framework.

It's a random-controlled methodology, so that we'll have a group of families, who are participating in the pilot who will receive benefits and a comparable group that will be tracking simultaneously, so that the outcomes for those two groups will be definitive in whether or not these incentives have actually changed the investment and health education and workforce development that we're looking to invest in.
Now, as I understand it, this program is modeled after a similar program, which started in Mexico some years ago.
And I know you and Mayor Bloomberg visited that program in Mexico last spring.
Will something that works - I gather, largely, in rural areas of Mexico, could it be able to work in New York City?
Well, Neal, that is the question.

And we found it intriguing enough when the mayor appointed a commission to study the experience of poverty here in New York City and asked them to find innovations across the country, and now we discovered across the world, of things that might make a difference.
This program, the Conditional Cash Transfer program, it came up time and time again.

And quite frankly, initially, when we heard it, we didn't really think that it was going to be relevant to us here in New York City because the economies of those countries, where they are in place, tend to be very poor.

But the more we looked at it, the more we realize that there is many things in common with areas of very high concentration of poverty here in New York City, where there is such isolation of those communities from the opportunities that exist just a couple of subway stops away until it really - it - we were asking ourselves the question, can this very different approach work here as well as it has worked in other countries?
So why?
What's the goal here?
Is the goal behavior modification?
Or is it to help eradicate poverty?
The goal is to invest in the human capital, in the households, where poverty, not only exists now but has the strong likelihood of existing into the next generation.

And we want to break that cycle by changing the outcomes for the children in the household, around their well-being on health matters, on, you know, dental visits, and changing their outcomes in their education, not just school attendance, but the - how they do on standardized exams and whether or not they're advancing through the grade levels at age-appropriate times.
Then, we're building that international Conditional Cash Transfer model by adding in an adult workforce component - incentivizing full-prime employment and skills development.

The entire goal is not to build a safety net around the family while they're in poverty rather, rather it's to invest in all of those things that we know will break the cycle of poverty across the generations.

We don't want just to have transaction benefits, sort of one-offs, if you will.
We very much want to see that those activities become quite habit-forming.

And so having - incentivizing, for instance, a parent-teacher conference, it's not just about having the parent go and talk to the teacher on that one or two times a year when the opportunity is available, but creating the habit of a stronger link in engagement in their child's education by being demanding, quite frankly, of the teacher and the school around the quality of the education, and more demanding of themselves in terms of understanding what it is that is challenging their child's learning.
